questions.text: Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the ratio of __________
questions.solution:
Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the ratio of 1:5. Sulfamethoxazole is an intermediate-acting sulfonamide with a plasma half-life of around 10 hours. Trimethoprim also has a similar plasma half-life and therefore combined with sulfamethoxazole.

Due to a difference in pharmacokinetic (absorption in GIT) properties of the two drugs, this cannot be achieved by administering them at a dose having the same ratio. Therefore, it is administered at a dose ratio of 1:5 (trimethoprim: sulfamethoxazole) which leads to a plasma ratio of 1:20.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with schizoaffective disorder was recently prescribed a different antipsychotic drug instead of the one she was usually taking. She is also on sertraline. She presented a month later, complaining of breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and amenorrhea. Investigations revealed highly elevated prolactin levels. The drug most likely prescribed was?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperprolactinemia secondary to the use of risperidone, an atypical antipsychotic that can be used in schizoaffective disorder.

The clinical symptoms are indicative of hyperprolactinemia, most likely caused by the dopamine antagonist action of risperidone. Normally, prolactin secretion is inhibited by dopamine. Therefore, drugs that act as dopamine antagonists lead to loss of this inhibitory action and cause hyperprolactinemia. This results in symptoms like breast engorgement, galactorrhea, amenorrhea in women, and infertility in men. 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic indicated in the management of schizophrenia, acute mania or mixed with bipolar disorder, aggressive episodes in autism spectrum disorder, etc. It is an antagonist of the serotonin 5-HT2A, dopamine D2, a1-adrenergic, a2-adrenergic, and histamine H1 receptors.

In schizoaffective disorder, symptoms of mania or depression develop concurrently with the major symptoms of schizophrenia. Thus, they are treated with mood stabilizers for manic episodes (like carbamazepine) or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (like sertraline) for depressive episodes. Antipsychotics are prescribed for psychotic symptoms.

In this patient, sertraline was administered along with risperidone. The combined use of risperidone and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (as in this patient) can result in a significant elevation of prolactin levels. This is due to the CYP2D6 enzyme inhibitory actions of SSRIs, thereby inhibiting the metabolism of other CYP2D6 substrates. 

This hyperprolactinemia can be rapidly reversed by discontinuing the drug or switching to other low potency/ prolactin sparing (eg. quetiapine) atypical antipsychotics. In case, risperidone needs to be continued, administering bromocriptine can alleviate the symptoms. 

Other options:

Brexpiprazole, clozapine, and aripiprazole are atypical antipsychotics. they do not have any effect on prolactin secretion.

questions.text: Identify the drug which causes this adverse effect ________
questions.solution:
Ergotamine causes occlusion of peripheral blood vessels in susceptible persons. It acts as a partial agonist and antagonist at α adrenoreceptors and all subtypes of 5HT1 and 5HT2 serotonin receptors.

The numbness progressing to bluish discoloration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. It can lead to gangrene if left untreated eventually leading to amputation. Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of ergotamine.

Contraindications for ergotamine: 

  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Fever and/or sepsis
  • Pregnancy
  • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus has been prescribed pioglitazone. What will you tell her when she asks about the most common adverse effect of thiazolidinediones?
questions.solution:
The most common adverse effects of the thiazolidinediones are weight gain and edema.

Thiazolidinediones are a selective agonist of nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ). They modulate the expression of genes involved in lipid and glucose metabolism, insulin signal transduction, and adipocyte differentiation. These effects increase the sensitivity of the tissues to insulin.

Pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are used to treat patients with type 2 diabetes. They are known to cause fluid retention and edema and therefore avoided in patients who have heart failure. 

Pioglitazone is metabolized in the liver and constant liver function monitoring is required as it is hepatotoxic. It is thus contraindicated in liver disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was diagnosed with pulmonary artery hypertension. He was prescribed an endothelin receptor antagonist for the management of the same. After starting the drug, he developed nasal congestion and pharyngitis. Which of the following drugs was prescribed?
questions.solution:
The drug prescribed is bosentan. 

The clinical scenario of the development of nasal congestion and pharyngitis after administration of an endothelin receptor antagonist given for the treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension suggests that the drug prescribed is bosentan.

  • ETA - This receptor is localized on the pulmonary artery smooth muscle cell. It is a G-protein coupled receptor and acts via the IP3-DAG pathway elevating cytosolic Ca2+ thus causing vasoconstriction.
  • ETB - This receptor is present on the pulmonary artery smooth muscle cell and endothelial cell. It is a G-protein coupled receptor and on activation, the ETB receptors on the endothelial cells increase the production of PGI2, NO and inhibit ET-1 production.

Endothelin receptor antagonists act by either non-selectively inhibiting both endothelin receptors or by selectively inhibiting ETA receptors only. The nonselective endothelin receptor antagonists are bosentan and macitentan. The selective endothelin receptor antagonists are ambrisentan and sitaxsentan. Sitaxsentan is the most selective ETA receptor antagonist. These drugs are predominantly used in the treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension.

Side effects:

  • Headache
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Nasal congestion/pharyngitis
  • Hepatotoxicity -  needs monitoring and contraindicated in patients with mild-moderate liver disease.
  • Teratogenic - contraindicated in pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A- Epoprostenol is a synthetic PGI2, It acts by inhibiting myosin light chain kinase and activating K+ channels. It is the mainstay of treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension, particularly in advanced stages. The important side effects include myalgia, jaw pain, nausea, flushing, and systemic hypotension.

Option C- Inhaled NO acts by activation of soluble guanylyl cyclase → activates cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An important side effect is methemoglobinemia.

Option D- Sildenafil acts by competitive inhibition of phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE5). Important side effects are headache, flushing and blue-green vision.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with the following finding. Her medical history includes hypertension for which she has been taking regular medications for the past 3 months. Which of the following medication is most likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows pitting pedal edema in a hypertensive patient. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) like amlodipine are most likely to be associated with peripheral edema.

The frequency of CCB- induced peripheral edema is both drug-specific (i.e more potent drugs like amlodipine will be associated with higher rates of developing edema) and dose-dependent (i.e incidence of edema increases with an increase in drug dosage and chronicity of its usage). It is more common among females.

CCB-induced peripheral edema occurs due to a disproportionate decrease in the arteriolar resistance than in the venous circulation, resulting in increased hydrostatic pressure in the precapillary circulation. This leads to a fluid shift into the interstitial compartment causing edema.

Treatment:

  • Dose reduction.
  • Interclass switching of CCB - switch to non-dihydropyridines like verapamil, and diltiazem.
  • Addition of a venodilator - ACE inhibitor, ARBs, Nitrates.
  • Others - compression stockings, avoiding prolonged upright position.
  • Definitive treatment would be discontinuation of the CCB and switching to another class of antihypertensives.

Other options:

Option A: Common side effects of ACE inhibitors like enalapril include hypotension, hyperkalemia, dry cough, rashes, urticaria, dysgeusia, gastrointestinal upset, headache, and dizziness.

Option B: Telmisartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARBs), causes adverse effects such as hypotension, hyperkalemia, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

Option D: Adverse effects of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide are hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperglycemia, hyperuricemia, hypercalcemia, rashes, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding carbapenems.

choices.text: They act by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis.
Enterococcus faecium is resistant to imipenem.
Cilastatin is administered along with meropenem.
Ertapenem has longer half life than imipenem.

questions.solution:
Cilastatin, a dehydropeptidase inhibitor, is administered with imipenem (and not meropenem) to prevent its inactivation by renal dehydropeptidase.

Meropenem, doripenem, and ertapenem are resistant to inactivation by the enzyme and hence do not need cilastatin.

Other options:

  • Carbapenems are structurally related to beta-lactams and act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.
  • Enterococcus faecium, methicillin-resistant strains of staphylococci, Clostridium difficile, Burkholderia cepacia, and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia are resistant to imipenem.
  • Ertapenem has longer half-life than imipenem, meropenem and can be given as one daily dose.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs act via the mechanism depicted in the illustration shown below?
  1. Dobutamine
  2. Interferon
  3. Imatinib
  4. Atropine
  5. Verapamil
  6. Misoprostol
questions.solution:
The given illustration shows the G-protein-coupled receptor pathway for signalling. The drugs that function via this mechanism are dobutamine, propranolol, atropine, misoprostol, montelukast. 

Functional families of GPCRs include beta-adrenergic receptors, muscarinic cholinergic receptors, eicosanoid receptors, and thrombin receptors.

G proteins act as inhibitory and excitatory because of differences in the alpha subunit.

In general, Gs and Gq subtypes are excitatory whereas Gi is inhibitory.

Resting-state:

  • G protein heterotrimer consisting of alpha, beta and gamma subunits forms a complex with G-protein-coupled receptors at the intracellular domain. The extracellular domain of GPCR has the binding domain for hormones and G protein subunits do not directly bind them. 
  • The alpha subunit is bound to GDP 

Binding of ligand results in an activated state: 

  • Alpha subunit undergoes a conformational change
  • Release of GDP and binding of GTP
  • GTP bound alpha subunit dissociates from beta-gamma subunit
  • Both alpha subunit and beta-gamma subunit bind to and regulate effectors only when they are separated 

The illustration below shows the pathway.

Other options:

  • Interferon acts through cytokine receptors, which belong to the structural family of transmembrane, non-enzymes.
  • Imatinib acts via the receptor tyrosine kinases, which belongs to the structural family of transmembrane enzymes.
  • Verapamil acts via the voltage-gated ion channel.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient, who had undergone renal transplantation, presents to you with severe pain along the back of the leg above the heels. He reports that he has been taking some antibiotics without any doctor's prescription. You suspect Achilles tendon rupture. It is usually seen as a side effect of which of the following antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Achilles tendon rupture and tendinitis are associated side effects of quinolones like ciprofloxacin.

Elderly patients (>60 years), patients on corticosteroids, and solid organ transplant recipients are at higher risk of developing this risk factor. 

Fluoroquinolones inhibit topoisomerase IV in gram-positive bacteria. Normally, during replication, to prevent excessive positive supercoiling of the strands, DNA gyrase nicks double-stranded DNA and introduces negative supercoils. Fluoroquinolones, by inhibiting DNA gyrase (in gram-negative bacteria), result in the production of damaged DNA. This is finally digested by exonucleases, resulting in bactericidal action.

Fluoroquinolones are used in the treatment of urinary tract infections, prostatitis, and gastrointestinal, and respiratory infections, and as a second-line drug in anti-tubercular therapy. They are avoided in children and pregnant women.

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones are arthralgia, tendon rupture, Clostridium difficile colitis, dysglycemia, prolonged QT interval, rashes, hallucinations, delirium, and seizures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man came with abdominal cramps, nausea, diarrhea for the past two days. He also reports having body pain, a runny nose, and teary eyes. On examination, his pupils are dilated and he frequently keeps yawning. On probing further, he reluctantly says that he uses recreational drugs. His blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg and his heart rate is 110. Which of the following drugs is used for the maintenance therapy for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Methadone is used for the maintenance of opioid (heroin) dependence as a substitute therapy because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. 

Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. Because of its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in protracted withdrawal symptoms.

Treatment for opioid dependence

Maintainance phase: to decrease the severity of withdrawal symptoms.

  • Oral mu agonist: a safe substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms.
  • Long acting agonist: buprenorphine can also be used.
  • Clonidine, lofexidine reduce the withdrawal symptoms and anxiety
  • Methadone, buprenorphine, LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol): opioid agonists which reduce craving.

Relapse prevention phase:

  • Naltrexone: An opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects.

Other options:

Option A- Methylmorphine (codeine)is an opioid agonist used for the relief of severe chronic cancer pain and suppression of cough. 

Option C- Meperidine belongs to a class of opioid analgesics and is similar to morphine. It is used to treat moderate to severe pain. 

Option D- Methylphenidate is a stimulant used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

questions.text: Drug of choice for ethylene glycol poisoning is
questions.solution:
Intravenous fomepizole is the standard treatment for ethylene glycol poisoning. Intravenous ethanol is an alternative.

Fomepizole is administerd intravenously in methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning with a loading dose of 15 mg/kg

Ethylene glycol poisoning:

  • Ethylene glycol is used as heat exchangers, in antifreeze formulations and as industrial solvents.
  • Ethylene glycol is relatively harmless but it forms metabolites like toxic aldehydes (converted to acids) and oxalate that are harmful.
  • Inhibition of formation of toxic metabolites by adminitering fomepizole or ethanol is the mainstay of treatment.

Clinical features:

  • Initial excitation followed by CNS depression.
  • After 4-12 hours, severe metabolic acidosis due to acid metabolites and lactate.
  • Finally, renal insufficiency due to deposition of oxalate in renal tubules.

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis was started on antitubercular therapy. Among the following antitubercular drugs given below, which of the following option selects all the drugs that have a bactericidal action?
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Rifampicin
  3. Pyrazinamide
  4. Ethambutol
  5. Streptomycin
questions.solution:
Ethambutol is the only bacteriostatic agent among the given options. All the options are examples of bactericidal drugs. Therefore, option D (1, 2, 3, 5) is the right answer. 

Bactericidal antituberculosis agents (RIPS)

  • R: Rifampicin (R)
  • I: Isoniazid (H)
  • P: Pyrazinamide (Z)
  • S: Streptomycin (S)

Treatment regimens for pulmonary tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis consist of an initial 2-month phase of a 4-drug regimen, followed by a continuation phase of an additional 4 months of isoniazid and rifampin for pulmonary tuberculosis.

Isoniazid is used for the treatment of tuberculosis (as part of combination therapy) or for latent tuberculosis infection (as monotherapy or part of combination therapy). The antimicrobial activity of INH is selective for mycobacteria, likely due to its ability to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis, which interferes with cell wall synthesis, thereby producing a bactericidal effect 

Rifampicin is thought to inhibit bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which appears to occur as a result of drug binding in the polymerase subunit deep within the DNA/RNA channel, facilitating direct blocking of the elongating RNA. Along with Isoniazid, Rifampicin is also given in both the initial phase and continuation phase of the treatment of TB.

Pyrazinamide is most commonly used for the treatment of active tuberculosis (TB) during the initial phase of therapy only(generally the first two months of treatment), in combination with other agents. The spectrum of pyrazinamide is relatively narrow; it demonstrates clinically significant antibacterial activity only against Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium africanum.

Streptomycin is an injectable drug, also a bactericidal drug used sometimes in the initial phase of treatment of pulmonary TB.

Ethambutol is the only drug in the initial phase which is an example of a bacteriostatic drug. There is evidence that the drug exerts its bacteriostatic activity by virtue of inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme that polymerizes arabinose into arabinan and then arabinogalactan, a mycobacterial cell wall constituent.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 70 year old female presents to the OPD with symptoms of pain in both the knees since the past two years. She has been on calcium and vitamin D supplementation and is doing regular physical exercise. X-ray of the knee joint showed the following. Which would be the first line drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
Bisphosphonates are used in the first-line management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. X Ray shows periarticular osteopenia around the knee joint.

Bisphosphonates are analogs of pyrophosphate. They specifically inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Mechanism of action:

Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling. They remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Other Drugs:

  • Denosumab - This is an antibody to the RANK ligand. It prevents the activation of RANK which is required for the proliferation of osteoclasts. Therefore, it decreases bone resorption.
  • Parathyroid hormone - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone analog. At low and intermittent doses, they can promote bone formation.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) - They act on the estrogen receptors and prevent bone resorption. Eg. raloxifene.
  • Strontium ranelate - It is thought to increase bone formation and reduce bone resorption.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is indicated for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, adenosine is the drug of choice for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.

  • Adenosine is an ultra-short acting drug with half-life being less than 10 seconds.
  • It activates an inward rectifier K+ current along with inhibition of calcium current. The results of these actions are marked hyperpolarization and suppression of calcium- dependent action potentials.
  • When given as a bolus dose, adenosine directly inhibits AV nodal conduction but has lesser effects on the SA node.
  • Currently, Adenosine is used for prompt conversion of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to sinus rhythm because of its high efficacy (90–95%) and very short duration of action. It is usually given in a bolus dose of 6 mg followed by a dose of 12 mg, if required.
  • Flushing, shortness of breath and chest burning are some of its adverse effects.

questions.text: A middle-aged hypertensive man presents with acute onset pain and swelling on his toe over the left foot. Local examination showed a swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot, as shown below. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs can be safely administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute onset pain and swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot suggests the diagnosis of acute gout. Losartan can be safely administered to this patient as it is a uricosuric drug.

Losartan is competitive angiotensin I (AT1) receptor antagonist, which binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. Uses of losartan are:

  • Antihypertensive
  • Renoprotective drug in diabetes mellitus
  • Stroke prophylaxis
  • Portal hypertension in cirrhosis without compromising renal function
  • Anti-aggregant as it is a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor 
  • Uricosuric drug as it inhibits reabsorption and actively secretes uric acid in the proximal convoluted tubule

Adverse effects include fetopathic potential, hypotension, renal insufficiency, and hyperkalemia. 

Other options:

Option B: Atenolol is a beta blocker that has been proven to increase serum uric acid levels; hence, it is avoided.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic; it is not used in patients with gout as it increases the uric acid level.

Option D: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes hyperuricemia due to increased reabsorption of uric acid. It is not used in patients with gout.

questions.text: Which of the following statement best describes a partial agonist?

choices.text: High affinity and high intrinsic activity
High affinity and low intrinsic activity
Low affinity and high intrinsic activity
High affinity and zero intrinsic activity

questions.solution:
Partial agonists have high affinity and low intrinsic activity.

According to the receptor occupation theory, the ability of a drug to bind to a receptor is its affinity, and the ability to induce functional change in the receptor is designated as the intrinsic activity (IA) of the drug. These 2 properties are independent of each other.

  • Full agonists: These agents have both affinity and maximum intrinsic activity. Examples are histamine, adrenaline, etc.
  • Partial agonists: They have affinity but submaximal intrinsic activity. e.g pentazocine on µ opiod receptors.
  • Inverse agonists are drugs that have an affinity for a receptor but the intrinsic activity is opposite to that of an agonist. Eg: chlorpheniramine on H1 receptors.
  • Competitive antagonists: These agents have affinity and no intrinsic activity. Eg:propanolol, atropine etc.

Chloroquine, an anti-malarial drug may get deposited in the cornea leading to whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata/vortex keratopathy/ Fleisher vortex/ whorl keratopathy.

  • On short-term therapy, chloroquine causes blurring of vision and diplopia, which are reversible by stopping the drug.
  • Long-term (>5 years) use of high doses of chloroquine causes keratopathy, pigmentary retinopathy, and optic atrophy.
  • Hydroxychloroquine has lower ocular toxicity compared to chloroquine.
  • The maximum permissible dosage of chloroquine is 6mg/Kg in 24 hours, while that of hydroxychloroquine is 4.5mg/Kg in 24 hours.

Long-term treatment with chloroquine may sometimes cause whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata.

  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine

  • Cardiovascular: Atrioventricular block, bundle branch block, cardiac arrhythmia, cardiac failure, cardiomyopathy, ECG changes, hypotension, torsades de pointes, ventricular fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for alprostadil use?

choices.text: Maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus

questions.solution:
Alprostadil is used for the temporary maintenance of the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates, keeping the ductus arteriosus open. 

Alprostadil is a natural PGE1 analog. PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle.

The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta) is functionally closed at 10-15 hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days after birth.

Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left heart syndrome,  and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus. Closure of ductus arteriosus in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia, and cyanosis. Maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus in neonates is essential in some congenital heart diseases before corrective surgery is performed, and alprostadil is used for this purpose.

Alprostadil is also used in the treatment of critical limb ischemia, erectile dysfunction, and pulmonary hypertension. Treatment with alprostadil results in an improvement in ulcers, pain, and limb salvage rates in critical limb ischemia patients.

Side effects of alprostadil include pain, bruising, and priapism. If priapism occurs, the patient will need urgent medical attention, which might include aspiration of blood, surgical shunt, or intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine for cavernosal vasoconstriction.

PGE1 analogs like alprostadil, misoprostol, and rioprostil can also be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply.

Other options:

Option A: PGF2α analog carboprost is used as an abortifacient in the second trimester.

Option B: Indomethacin a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug is used for the closure of patent ductus arteriosus.

Option D: Dinoprostone (PGE2) can be used for the induction of labor.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl was brought with complaints of vomiting and altered consciousness. She was recently diagnosed with an influenza infection and was started on an antipyretic for fever. Laboratory tests showed increased levels of liver enzymes but normal serum bilirubin levels. What could have been the prescribed antipyretic in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical history suggests an adverse reaction to the given antipyretic medication and describes Reye's syndrome. Reye's syndrome can be precipitated in children with viral infection and concomitant use of salicylates like aspirin.

Reye syndrome is an acute encephalopathy that may follow a viral upper respiratory tract infection (influenza or varicella). It is precipitated in a genetically susceptible person by the interaction between viral infection and exposure to salicylates and/or antiemetics.

Clinically children present with acute onset vomiting and features of encephalopathy like delirium, altered consciousness, confusion, and lethargy.

Liver dysfunction is present in all cases and presents with coagulopathy and laboratory evidence of elevated serum levels of aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, and ammonia. But, bilirubin levels remain normal and the patient does not develop jaundice.

A biopsy of the liver in a patient with Reye's syndrome shows microvesicular infiltration of fat in the hepatocytes. Reye syndrome is a life-threatening adverse effect, and patients must also be screened for fatty acid oxidation and fatty acid transport defects.

Another salicylate medication that risks the development of Reye's syndrome is bismuth subsalicylate.

Other options:

Mefenamic acid, ibuprofen, and acetaminophen are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs that can be used as antipyretics in children and are not associated with the development of Reye's syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient has been prescribed a drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of his chronic gout. What is this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of chronic gout is pegloticase.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase) that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite. It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated. The efficacy of this drug gets lowered if antibodies are produced against the drug, which occurs in many patients. This also increases the risk of infusion reactions. 

Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase. It is indicated for the initial management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in patients with malignancies who are on chemotherapy. The efficacy is limited by the production of antibodies to the drug.

Gout occurs due to the precipitation of urate crystals in the tissues with a subsequent inflammatory response. In an acute episode of gout, there is painful distal monoarthritis which can lead to joint destruction, subcutaneous tophi, and renal calculi. Management of gout includes:

  • Reduction of pain and inflammation: NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids
  • Inhibition of the formation of urate: Allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Promotion of urate excretion: Probenecid, lesinurad

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall reducing the inflammatory response.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5?
questions.solution:
Step 5 in the given life cycle shows the integration of the viral DNA into the host genome. Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor and is active against both HIV-1 and HIV-2. It can be used in adults and children >1 month old. 

It is advised for patients to consume antacids and sucralfate, 6 hours before or 2 hours after raltegravir intake.

It may cause headaches, nausea, weakness and fatigue. Rarely, it can lead to drug reactions with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome.

The steps involved in the lifecycle of HIV as given in the image are described as follows:

  • Step 1: Binding of HIV-1 to the cell membrane of a CD4+ cell
  • Step 2: HIV-1 enters the cell via interaction with the membrane glycoproteins
  • Step 3: Reverse transcription of the viral genetic material using the virus' reverse transcriptase enzyme
  • Step 4: The HIV-1 genome travels into the nucleus
  • Step 5: The viral genome integrates into the host's DNA through the integrase enzyme
  • Step 6: The HIV-1 proviral genome undergoes transcription with the host DNA
  • Step 7: The viral messenger RNA (mRNA) undergoes translation to produce new viral proteins
  • Steps 8 and 9: Assembly and maturation of the virion

Other options:

Option B: Enfuvirtide acts at step 2 in the given image. It blocks gp41 of the cell membrane and blocks the entry of the virus into the cell. It prevents the free viral particles from invading new CD4+ cells. It is effective against HIV-1.

Option C: Tenofovir acts at step 3 in the given image. It is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is effective against HIV-1,2 and hepatitis B infections. It is used in adults and children >2 years old. It can also be used for pre-exposure prophylaxis. 

Option D: Zidovudine also acts at step 3 in the given image. It is an NRTI and is effective against HIV-1,2 and Human T-cell Lymphoma Virus (HTLV). It can be used in adults and children. It can also be used to prevent mother-to-child transmission.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to the hospital with vomiting. He was prescribed metoclopramide, following which he developed spasms of facial muscles, difficulty in speech, and torticollis. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the treatment of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has developed symptoms of dystonia due to metoclopramide. Diphenhydramine is used in drug-induced dystonia.

Metoclopramide has dopamine receptor antagonist, 5HT4 agonist, and 5HT3 antagonist properties. It is indicated in patients with gastroparesis and is also used in reducing nausea and vomiting that often accompany GI dysmotility syndromes.

Dopamine receptor antagonist property is responsible for extrapyramidal symptoms. The dystonic reaction is one of the extrapyramidal symptoms. Features include spasms of muscles of the tongue, face, neck, and back. It can be treated with diphenhydramine or benztropine.

Other extrapyramidal symptoms include parkinsonian-like symptoms that may occur several weeks after initiation of therapy. It responds to treatment with anticholinergic or antihistaminic drugs and reverses on discontinuation of metoclopramide. Tardive dyskinesia can develop in patients treated for a prolonged period with metoclopramide.

Other options:

Option A: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. It inhibits MAOA and MAOB to prevent the breakdown of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin. It is used in the treatment of major depression. The major adverse effects include weight gain, sexual dysfunction, and hypertensive crisis if taken along with tyramine-containing foods/ beverages.

Option C: Chlorpromazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist and is classified under typical antipsychotics. They are noted to improve the positive symptoms of schizophrenia and acute mania. The major adverse effects are extrapyramidal side effects, sedation, weight gain, hypotension, metabolic adverse effects, and photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2. He says that he does not prefer injections. He had 1 episode of pancreatitis 3 years back and has a history of colon cancer in his family. He also has been diagnosed with heart failure and has been taking medications. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Glimepiride can be given to this patient. It belongs to the class called sulfonylureas.

Sulfonylureas act by closing the ATP-sensitive K channels in the beta-cells of the pancreas. This closure causes cell membrane depolarization and the release of insulin. They are readily absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and therefore can be given orally. Important sulfonylureas are glimepiride, glipizide, glyburide, etc.

Important adverse effects are hypoglycemia, vomiting, cholestatic jaundice, agranulocytosis, and aplastic and hemolytic anemias. They can also cause a disulfiram-like reaction. They should be used with caution in pregnancy, lactation, and significant hepatic or renal insufficiency (for the older forms).

Other options

Option A- Pioglitazone belongs to a class of thiazolidinediones. It activates the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ) and increases insulin sensitivity. Apart from weight gain, it also causes edema and fluid retention. It increases the plasma volume and is therefore unsuitable for heart failure patients.

Option B- Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist. It stimulates insulin secretion, inhibits glucagon release, delays gastric emptying, reduces food intake, and normalizes fasting and postprandial insulin secretion. It is given subcutaneously. It can also cause pancreatitis, and therefore is not used in patients with a history or risk of developing pancreatitis.

Option D- Teduglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) analog. It enhances the growth of intestinal mucosa. It is used in the treatment of short bowel syndrome and not diabetes mellitus. It is administered parenterally and discontinued in patients with active gastrointestinal malignancy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female has complaints of marked dryness in her mouth associated with difficulty in swallowing. Schirmer's test is suggestive of severe dry eye. An immunoassay shows the presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B antibodies. Which of the following drugs would be most helpful, with fewer side effects, in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms together with the presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B antibodies are suggestive of Sjogren syndrome. Cevimeline would be the best drug for treatment in this case.

Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist with an affinity for both M1 and M3 receptors on the lacrimal and salivary glands. While M1 activation results in increased secretion, M3 activation results in smooth muscle contraction, and expulsion of the secretions.

Cevimeline enhances lacrimal secretions in Sjögren’s syndrome.

Cevimeline has a long-lasting sialogogic action. The usual dose is 30 mg three times daily. It has fewer side effects than non-selective pilocarpine.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male complained of occasional acute attacks of intense panic and anxiety with marked physical symptoms, including shortness of breath, palpitations, sweating, tremors, and fear of impending doom. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described are diagnostic of panic disorder, which are commonly treated with benzodiazepines such as Clonazepam.

Benzodiazepines act by binding to specific GABA-A receptor subunits at the central nervous system (CNS) neuronal synapses. This facilitates the GABA-mediated chloride ion channel opening frequency.

Therapeutic uses of benzodiazepines:

  • To treat acute anxiety states, panic attacks, and generalized anxiety disorder.
  • Treatment of insomnia and other sleep disorders.
  • Also used for relaxation of the skeletal muscle, as an adjunct in anaesthesia, and seizure disorders.

Overdose of benzodiazepines may cause dose-dependent depressive effects, which include: sedation, amnesia, hypnosis, anaesthesia, coma, and respiratory depression.

Other options:

  • Propranolol may be used for treating performance anxiety, such as stage fright or fear of public speaking. However, propranolol is not primarily indicated for the treatment of the panic disorder. However, they are occasionally used due to side-effects such as hypotension.
  • Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist. It is indicated in the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose, or for reversal of the sedative effects caused by benzodiazepines.
  • Buspirone is a 5-HT receptor agonist. It is used in the treatment of generalised anxiety states (not for other anxiety disorders or panic attacks).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. Per speculum examination of the vagina is done as shown below. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows budding yeast cells. The clinician prescribes an oral medication. What is the likely mechanism of action of the given medication?

choices.text: Forms pores in the fungal cell wall

questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of curdy white vaginal discharge and the KOH smear showing budding yeast cells are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The oral medication given in this condition is fluconazole which acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

Azole group of antifungal are grouped into two types :

  • Imidazole- clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazole- Itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impaired conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Therapeutic uses of fluconazole-

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis can be treated with fluconazole by taking 100–200 mg a day for 7–14 days. Uncomplicated vaginal candidiasis can be effectively treated with a single 150 mg dose. Treatment of candidemia in nonimmunosuppressed patients involves a loading dosage of 800 mg, followed by 400 mg daily.
  • For the first eight weeks of the consolidation phase of the therapy of cryptococcal meningitis in individuals with AIDS, fluconazole is administered.
  • Due to its excellent CSF penetration and significantly lower morbidity than intrathecal amphotericin B, fluconazole is the medication of choice for treating coccidioidal meningitis. Fluconazole is similar to itraconazole in treating various types of coccidioidomycosis.

Other options

Option A- Amphotericin B acts by forming pores in the fungal cell membrane. It has also been found that it forms aggregates that sequester ergosterol from lipid bilayers, leading to fungal cell death. It is indicated in invasive mucormycosis, fungal endophthalmitis following pars plana vitrectomy, and induction therapy in cryptococcal meningitis. 

Option B- Griseofulvin acts by inhibiting microtubule assembly, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. It is also effective in treating ringworm of glabrous skin, tinea cruris, tinea corprosis, tinea pedis, and tinea of the hands and beard. 

Option C- Terbinafine acts by inhibiting epoxidation of fungal squalene that reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. It is helpful for treating nail onychomycosis in adults and tinea capitis.

questions.text: As a researcher employed in a pharmaceutical company, you are involved in a clinical trial. A monoclonal antibody for the treatment of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is entering phase III of the clinical trial. Which of these statements correctly describes this phase?

choices.text: 250 healthy volunteers from the general population, randomized and blinded
2946 patients with RCC, randomized and double-blinded
96 healthy volunteers in an open-label study, to study adverse effects
5548 patients with RCC in an open-label observational study

questions.solution:
Phase III trials are usually done on 500–3000 patients with the disease, and these are randomized double-blinded studies.

Phase III trials are usually considered pivotal trials that are necessary for the approval of the majority of drugs. They are also called a multisite trial, which is done for 3–5 years. This phase confirms the efficacy of the drug. It is also done to study the long-term or rare side effects of this drug. 

When the initial phase III trials are complete, the sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) applies to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is called either a new drug application (NDA) or a biologics license application (BLA).

Note: In some drugs related to rare diseases or oncology, phase II studies are considered pivotal, and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

Other phases of clinical trials:

Preclinical trials are performed on animals and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed by the committee for the purpose of the control and supervision of experiments on animals (CPCSEA) in India. Standards for the conduct of clinical trials involving Indian subjects are laid down in good clinical practice (GCP).

Phase I clinical trials are performed on healthy volunteers in an open-label study to determine the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetic properties of the drug.

Phase II clinical trials are conducted to evaluate the appropriate dose range of the drug. It is evaluated on a small group of patients (50-500) with the target disease. Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease.

The study is designed to obtain proof of concept (potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase III studies).

Phase IV clinical trials are conducted after the drug is marketed and approved by regulatory authorities. It includes post-marketing surveillance and other studies that complement the earlier findings on the drug.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was treated with an intravenous diuretic for heart failure. Now he presents with  tinnitus,  vertigo, a sense of fullness in the ears and difficulty in hearing from the right ear. Examination shows Weber’s test localised to the left ear and Rinne’s test shows AC>BC in both ears.  The responsible offending agent acts most likely in which part of the nephron?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a drug-induced sensorineural type of hearing loss, and furosemide is likely to be associated with these side effects (ototoxicity). This is due to the adverse effect of IV furosemide used during his heart failure treatment. Furosemide acts on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

Interpretation of the given audiogram:

  • Red indicates right ear
  • O indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB. Hence AC is abnormal
  • < indicates BC and threshold is >25 dB. Hence BC is abnormal
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss
  • There is no Air-Bone gap
  • Hence it is right side sensorineural hearing loss

Since Weber is lateralised towards left, it indicates left sided conductive deafness or right sided sensorineural deafness. Since Rinne is positive on both ears, conductive deafness is ruled out. Therefore, it is Right sided sensorineural hearing loss.

Other options:

Carbonic anhydrase acts on the PCT. It is used for glaucoma, pseudotumor cerebri, metabolic alkalosis and cystine stone prevention.Due to their structural homology to the sulfonamides, they may cause bone marrow depression, skin toxicity, and allergic reactions.

Thiazides act on the DCT. It is used for treatment of hypertension and chronic edema. Their adverse effects are as follows

  • Hypotension
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypochloremia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Decrease glucose tolerance
  • May increase the lipid levels

ADH receptor antagonists like Tolvaptan act in medullary CT. Used for treating hyponatremia. They can cause hypokalemia, dehydration, liver damage (eps contraindicated in people with previous liver disease) as side effects.

Other common ototoxic drugs are:

  1. Antibiotics like Aminoglycosides ( gentamicin > tobramycin > amikacin > neomycin), erythromycin, tetracyclines.
  2. Chemotherapeutic agents like Cisplatin, Bleomycin and Nitrogen mustard.
  3. High dose aspirin, acetaminophen and NSAID’s
  4. Antimalarials like quinine and quinidine
  5. Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors like Sildenafil

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the characteristics of elimination plotted in orange?

choices.text: Fixed amount of drug is cleared per unit time
Exhibited by drugs such as phenytoin

questions.solution:
In the given image, the orange line depicts zero-order elimination. The incorrect statement about this type of elimination is that t½ remains constant. In zero-order elimination, the t½ is not constant and is less at low concentration and more at high concentration.

Zero-order kinetics denotes that the rate of elimination is constant regardless of the concentration of the drug. Here a fixed amount of drug is cleared per unit time. This is usually seen when the drugs saturate their elimination mechanisms. Therefore, as the concentration of the drug increases beyond metabolic saturation, clearance of the drug decreases as depicted by the orange line. Drugs such as phenytoin, and aspirin follow this type of elimination at higher concentrations. 

First-order kinetics denotes that the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration of the drug. Here a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated. The drugs following this elimination have a constant  t½. As the dosage of the drug increases, the clearance remains constant as the fraction of drug eliminated is constant as depicted by the black line. Most drugs follow this type of elimination.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman presented with features suggestive of thyrotoxicosis. Which of the following is not a treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
Radioactive iodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation. Therefore, it is not a treatment option in this patient.

Thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy:

The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil (PTU).

Methimazole and its prodrug (carbimazole) are usually avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenic risk. However, methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for PTU-associated liver failure. 

Subtotal thyroidectomy can be performed during the mid-trimester.

Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and causes the destruction of the fetal thyroid. Therefore, it is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady with grade 2 osteoarthritis is on treatment with NSAIDs. She developed heartburn and epigastric pain. An upper GI endoscopy revealed gastritis. Which of the following is the most appropriate advice for her pharmacologically?

choices.text: Stop NSAIDs and chew capsule pantoprazole for rapid action
Switch to etoricoxib instead of NSAIDs and use pantoprazole capsule without chewing
Use a combination of antacid and cimetidine for rapid healing
Switch to ranitidine along with sucralfate

questions.solution:
Among the given options, switching to etoricoxib instead of a non-selective COX inhibitor and using pantoprazole without chewing would be the most appropriate advice.

Selective COX2 inhibitors like etoricoxib are less likely to cause gastritis than non-selective COX inhibitors like aspirin or ibuprofen.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like pantoprazole are generally coated or available in capsule forms. Without this, it gets degraded by the action of gastric acid. Hence uncrushed PPI should be used 1/2 to 1 hour before the meals.

Other options:

Option A: NSAIDs may be stopped in view of gastric irritation and switched to another analgesic or surgical option might be undertaken. PPI should not be crushed.

Option C: A combination of H2 blockers like cimetidine and antacid should not be administered simultaneously, as the antacids reduce the absorption of all H2 blockers. At least a gap of 2 hours should be maintained.

Option D: Ranitidine increases the gastric pH (i.e. less acidic) which reduces sucralfate efficacy; hence the combination is incorrect. 

Note: Usage of ranitidine for any purpose has been banned by the FDA due to a potential carcinogenic agent in a few batches of this drug.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used in the treatment of overactive urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Tolterodine is commonly used in the treatment of the overactive urinary bladder. It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist. 

In an overactive bladder, there is an overactivity of the detrusor muscle due to the up-regulation of M3 receptors. Drugs that block these receptors such as tolterodine act by improving bladder capacity, reducing the frequency of bladder contractions, and lowering intravesicular pressure.

Anticholinergics are muscarinic receptor antagonists and parasympatholytics. The important uses of various anticholinergics are as follows:

  • Atropine - for AV block, organophosphorus poisoning, and refractive error testing in children (produces cycloplegic mydriasis)
  • Scopolamine/ hyoscine (transdermal patch) - for motion sickness
  • Ipratropium - for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and rhinorrhea 
  • Tolterodine - for childhood enuresis, overactive and neurogenic bladder
  • Pirenzepine (selective M1 receptor antagonist) - for peptic ulcer disease 
  • Benzhexol/ Trihexyphenidyl - for Parkinson's disease and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms
  • Dicyclomine (direct spasmolytic effect on GI smooth muscle) - for diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome
  • Glycopyrrolate (reduces secretions) - as a pre-anesthetic medication

Adverse effects of muscarinic antagonists include dryness of mouth, decreased sweating, thirst, mydriasis and blurring of vision, palpitations, and urinary retention. CNS effects include restlessness, hallucinations, and delirium.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about disulfiram?

choices.text: When used with alcohol, the patients feels drowsy, with chest discomfort and respiratory depression
It can be initiated even in minimally motivated person
Its action persists up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug

questions.solution:
Disulfiram is used in behavioural modification technique for alcohol de-addiction. The principle of action is aversive conditioning.

Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibitor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde dehydrogenase. Ethanol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of acetaldehyde. Increased acetaldehyde levels can cause flushing, pulsating headache, throbbing pain in head and neck, nausea, vomiting, rashes, respiratory difficulties, chest pain, autonomic manifestations and other aversive reactions.

Disulfiram can only be given to highly motivated individuals. Disulfiram should not be administered until the person has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours. The disulfiram-alcohol reaction may occur as long as 14 days after the last dose of disulfiram.

Disulfiram like reaction with alcohol ingestion is also seen with the following drugs:

  • Metronidazole
  • Sulfonylureas like chlorpropamide
  • Cephalosporins like cefoperazone, cefamandole

Other modalities of treatment:

  • Pharmacotherapy: Typically 5-10 days, treatment for detoxification: Benzodiazepine and chlordiazepoxide are the drugs of choice.
  • Rehabilitation programs: Typically 28-day programs, learn about relapse prevention and identification of triggers.
  • Maintenance phase: Baclofen, Acamprosate, Naltrexone, Topiramate, SSRI, Ondansetron
  • Psychotherapy: Group therapy such as Alcoholics Anonymous

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is undergoing coronary thrombolysis and requires tenecteplase for fibrinolytic therapy. Which of the following conditions is not an absolute contraindication to starting this drug?

choices.text: Ischemic stroke within the last 3 months

questions.solution:
Tenecteplase is used for fibrinolytic therapy. An active peptic ulcer is a relative contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy. Other options are absolute contraindications.

 Absolute Contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy:

  • Known malignant intracranial neoplasm
  • Prior intracranial hemorrhage
  • Ischemic stroke within the last 3 months
  • Known structural cerebral vascular lesion
  • Suspicion of aortic dissection
  • Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis (excluding menstrual bleeding)
  • Significant closed head trauma or facial trauma within 3 months

Relative Contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy:

  • Uncontrolled hypertension (systolic blood pressure >180 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure >110 mmHg)
  • Active peptic ulcer
  • Noncompressible vascular punctures
  • Traumatic or prolonged CPR or major surgery within 3 weeks
  • Recent (within 2–4 weeks) internal bleeding
  • For streptokinase: prior exposure (more than 5 days ago) or prior allergic reaction to streptokinase
  • Pregnancy
  • Current use of warfarin and INR >1.7

  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose

questions.solution:
Amphotericin B is an amphipathic molecule and incorporates itself in the cell membrane by actively binding to ergosterol (as shown in the image by 'C'). This results in the formation of amphotericin-induced pores which cause leakage of the intracellular contents ultimately resulting in cell death.

It is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be used against Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii, Coccidioides immitis, Aspergillus.

Amphotericin B also has antiprotozoal action along with antifungal properties and is effective against Leishmania.

Adverse effects of amphotericin B include:

  • Infusion-related fever and chills
  • Azotemia/nephrotoxicity- all lipid formulations of amphotericin B are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B
  • Renal tubular acidosis 
  • Renal wasting of potassium and magnesium
  • Hypochromic normocytic anemia- due to decreased erythropoietin production from the kidney.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient came to the hospital with a history of headaches, seizures, memory loss, and mood changes.  The given image is obtained by doing an MRI scan. Which of the following drugs is useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the MRI scan finding are suggestive of glioblastoma. Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy.

Temozolomide belongs to the triazene group of alkylating agents and is administered orally. The oral bioavailability of temozolomide is nearly 100%. It forms a methylating metabolite and kills cells in all phases of the cell cycle.

Glioblastoma is the most malignant astrocytic tumor - WHO grade IV. It spreads along the white matter tracts and crosses the midline via the corpus callosum, giving rise to the so-called butterfly glioma. 

Other options:

Option A- Streptozocin belongs to the nitrosourea group of alkylating agents and has a high affinity of islets of Langerhans. It is used in the treatment of pancreatic islet cell carcinoma and carcinoid tumors.

Option C- Ifosfamide belongs to the nitrogen mustard group of alkylating agents and an analog of cyclophosphamide. Ifosfamide is used in germ cell tumors of testes and sarcomas. It has maximum neurotoxicity which can be treated with methylene blue. It has a urothelial damaging capacity like cyclophosphamide which can be treated with MESNA (sodium-2-mercaptoethanol sulfonate).

Option D- Chlorambucil belongs to the nitrogen mustard group of alkylating agents and is an orally administered drug. It is almost exclusively used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

questions.solution:
Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the management of immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). Eltrombopag is also a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the treatment of ITP and severe aplastic anemia.

Other options:

Option A- Epoetin alfa and darbepoetin alfa are recombinant human erythropoietin. They can be used in the treatment of anemias associated with surgery, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, prematurity, and certain chronic inflammatory conditions. 

Option B- Filgrastim is a recombinant granulocyte colony-stimulating factor. It increases neutrophil production. It is used in the treatment of neutropenia. Important adverse reactions include bone pain, local skin reaction, and cutaneous necrotizing vasculitis.

Option C- Oprelvekin is a recombinant human IL-11. It increases thrombopoiesis. It is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia due to non-myeloid malignancies. Important adverse effects are fluid retention, tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath.

Sargramostim is a recombinant granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor. It stimulates myelopoiesis. Important adverse effects are bone pain, malaise, flu-like symptoms, diarrhea, dyspnea, and rash.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding digoxin, except:

choices.text: It is one of the cardiac glycosides
It can cause premature ventricular depolarisations
Hypermagnesemia increases the risk of digitalis induced arrhythmia

questions.solution:
Hypomagnesemia increases the risk of digitalis-induced arrhythmia. 

Digoxin is one of the cardiac glycosides which is derived from the digitalis plant and used clinically.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increase intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

Digoxin is 65–80% absorbed after oral administration. An almost two-third of the metabolite is excreted unchanged by kidney with half-life of 36-40 hours.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity include atrioventricular junctional rhythm, premature ventricular depolarizations, ventricular bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and second-degree AV blockade. After cardiovascular system, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea i.e., GIT effects are more pronounced. Altered color perception can also be seen in case of digoxin toxicity.

Factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity are:

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia- It increases the binding of the digoxin to the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. 
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia- Diuretics, amphotericin B, corticosteroids
  • Drugs that decrease digoxin elimination (inhibitors of P-glycoprotein)- Amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, itraconazole, propafenone, and flecainide
  • Renal failure
  • Hypothyroidism
